thread.title: Women raise their voices in regional Mexican music
thread.title_full: Women raise their voices in regional Mexican music - Houston Chronicle

author: chron.com
title: Women raise their voices in regional Mexican music
text:
Photo: Nick De La Torre, CHRONICLE Image 1 of / 25 25 The ladies of Los Horoscopos de Durango are two of the women representing in Regional Mexican music.
Click through to see more. Que vivan las mujeres ! The ladies of Los Horoscopos de Durango are two of the women representing in Regional Mexican music.
Click through to see more. Que vivan las mujeres ! Photo: Nick De La Torre, CHRONICLE Image 2 of 25 Jenni Rivera
The late Mexican-American singer's name was on everything from hair care products and makeup to her own tequila. Jenni Rivera
The late Mexican-American singer's name was on everything from hair care products and makeup to her own tequila. Photo: Reed Saxon, Associated Press Image 3 of 25 Chiquis The daughter of Jenni Rivera is following in her mother's footsteps. Chiquis The daughter of Jenni Rivera is following in her mother's footsteps. Photo: Alexander Tamargo, Getty Images Image 4 of 25 Ana Gabriel A true icon, Gabriel has done everything from mariachi to cumbias to pop. Ana Gabriel A true icon, Gabriel has done everything from mariachi to cumbias to pop. Photo: Dave Rossman, For The Chronicle Image 5 of 25 Selena Quintanilla The late singer is the most influential voice in Tejano music. Selena Quintanilla The late singer is the most influential voice in Tejano music. Image 6 of 25 Rocio Dúrcal The singer was known throughout the world as "the most Mexican Spaniard" for her iconic work in the ranchera folk-music style. She died in 2006. Rocio Dúrcal The singer was known throughout the world as "the most Mexican Spaniard" for her iconic work in the ranchera folk-music style. She died in 2006. Photo: BALLESTEROS, EFE Image 7 of 25 Shaila Durcal The daughter of the legendary Rocio Durcal struggled to find an identity as a ranchera singer. But she has found her niche in Latin pop. Shaila Durcal The daughter of the legendary Rocio Durcal struggled to find an identity as a ranchera singer. But she has found her niche in Latin pop. Photo: Jason Merritt, Getty Images Image 8 of 25 Paquita la del Barrio The ranchera icon rails against cheaters, liars and lazy men in her songs. Paquita la del Barrio The ranchera icon rails against cheaters, liars and lazy men in her songs. Photo: Balboa Recordings Image 9 of 25 ﻿Ana Bárbara The sexy grupero singer is a regular tabloid fixture. ﻿Ana Bárbara The sexy grupero singer is a regular tabloid fixture. Photo: handout Image 10 of 25 Shelly Lares The Texas singer says Olivia Newton-John and Linda Ronstadt are two of the biggest influence on her as an artist. Shelly Lares The Texas singer says Olivia Newton-John and Linda Ronstadt are two of the biggest influence on her as an artist. Photo: Handout Email Image 11 of 25 Linda Ronstadt The Roll Hall of Fame member is known for pop but has recorded mariachi and ranchera music. Linda Ronstadt The Roll Hall of Fame member is known for pop but has recorded mariachi and ranchera music. Photo: Amy Sussman, INVL Image 12 of 25 Lucero The singer and actress has recorded pop, mariachi and more. Lucero The singer and actress has recorded pop, mariachi and more. Photo: Rodrigo Varela, Getty Images Image 13 of 25 Elsa Garcia The Houston native is rumored to be prepping a comeback. Elsa Garcia The Houston native is rumored to be prepping a comeback. Photo: Courtesy Photo Image 14 of 25 Laura Leon The Mexican actress and singer, center, has done novelas and recorded music. Laura Leon The Mexican actress and singer, center, has done novelas and recorded music. Photo: Victor Chavez, WireImage Image 15 of 25 Graciela Beltran The singer, seen here with President George W. Bush, has recorded banda, mariachi and Tejano. Graciela Beltran The singer, seen here with President George W. Bush, has recorded banda, mariachi and Tejano. Photo: Mark Wilson, Getty Images Image 16 of 25 Nydia Rojas The talented singer released trio of acclaimed albums but hasn't been in the spotlight much lately. Nydia Rojas The talented singer released trio of acclaimed albums but hasn't been in the spotlight much lately. Photo: DAMIAN DOVARGANES, AP Image 17 of 25 Thalia OK, this one is a stretch. But the pop diva DID record a full album of banda versions of her hits. And it wasn't bad. Thalia OK, this one is a stretch. But the pop diva DID record a full album of banda versions of her hits. And it wasn't bad. Photo: EMI Image 18 of 25 Alicia Villarreal The Mexican pop and norteño singer fronted Limite then had solo success. Alicia Villarreal The Mexican pop and norteño singer fronted Limite then had solo success. Photo: Courtesy Universal Music Image 19 of 25 Pilar Montenegro The actress and singer scored a huge hit with "Quitame ese Hombre," which spent months on radio playlists and on the charts. Pilar Montenegro The actress and singer scored a huge hit with "Quitame ese Hombre," which spent months on radio playlists and on the charts. Photo: ALAN DIAZ, AP Image 20 of 25 Aracely Arambula The actress and singer had some success in the regional Mexican market. Aracely Arambula The actress and singer had some success in the regional Mexican market. Photo: Monica Schipper, Getty Images Image 21 of 25 Jennifer Pena The young singer wasn't even a teen when she became a Tejano star and soon crossed over to international audiences. Jennifer Pena The young singer wasn't even a teen when she became a Tejano star and soon crossed over to international audiences. Photo: D. Fahleson, Houston Chronicle Image 22 of 25 Ninel Conde The actress, known for her role in soap opera "Rebelde," scored some hits on the chart. Ninel Conde The actress, known for her role in soap opera "Rebelde," scored some hits on the chart. Photo: Chris Pizzello, Reuters Image 23 of 25 Diana Reyes The Mexican singer has enjoyed success with duranguense and sinaloense banda music. Diana Reyes The Mexican singer has enjoyed success with duranguense and sinaloense banda music. Photo: DR Promotions Image 24 of 25 Elida Reyna The Tejano singer is still performing and putting out music. Elida Reyna The Tejano singer is still performing and putting out music. Photo: DirectToArchive Image 25 of 25 Women raise their voices in regional Mexican music 1 / 25 Back to Gallery Los Horoscopos de Durango released its 17th album, "Vivir en Pecado," in September. The group has won Billboard Music Awards and a Latin Grammy. But sisters Vicky and Marisol Terrazas, who front the duranguense group, say it's been a struggle in a male-dominated genre.
RELATED: Stay up late with Los Horoscopos de Durango
"It's a shame. There's so much female talent out there. It's hard for women to actually be respected, to be taken into consideration, to be given the time to show our talent," Vicky says. "We're going to keep on doing it. So get out of the way."
The ladies perform 9 p.m. Friday at Club Crystal, 6680 U.S. 59 S. Tickets: $25-30, $65 VIP includes meet and greet. Call 713-278-2582 or go to clubpapi.com.
Peruse the above gallery for a look at other female singers who have made an impact in regional Mexican music.
